title: Bracknell News review of the year : January to June 2024
body_text:
As we prepare to head into 2025, we have had a look back at 2024 and what the top stories have been from each month.
From tragic accidents to stories of incredible feats, here we look at what happened through the first half of the year.
January
Post office scandal
In January 2023, the show Mr Bates vs The Post Office was aired, retelling the harrowing story of more than 700 branch managers who were wrongly accused of theft, fraud and false accounting by the Post Office for errors in its own computer system Horizon.
This prompted a petition against a Japanese technology company that has its UK headquarters in Bracknell to be blasted for bringing ‘shame on the town’.
As the tale has unfolded, IT company Fujitsu has come under fire for being the firm behind the Horizon accounting software that was used at the time by the Post Office. The company has its UK headquarters in Lovelace Road.
Bracknell resident Mark John launched a petition calling for those responsible to be brought to justice or for Fujitsu to leave the town altogether.
The Post Office Horizon scandal has been described as one of the most widespread miscarriages of justice in history, with 736 sub-postmasters prosecuted based on faulty information.
The Bracknell News spoke to Pam Stubbs, a former Berkshire sub-postmaster who spend her years fighting Post Office bosses for justice after her part in the Horizon scandal.
Read more here
Supporters rally for Ravi’s recovery
THOUSANDS of pounds was raised for a seven-year-old Bracknell boy who has been left with severe brain damage after suffering rare complications from an E.coli infection.
Despite initial mild symptoms of a stomach bug, Rafi Amer, from Jennett’s Park, was rushed to hospital experiencing severe pain. The seven year old was diagnosed with Stage 4 Kidney Failure.
After a series of life-threatening complications and two weeks in a coma, the once active youngster has been left with life-changing injuries that will now require specialist care. Rafi’s parents Laura and Dean Amer launched a GoFundMe to be able to facilitate Rafi’s care whenever he can return home.
Read more here
Signs that Dad had sepsis were missed in hospital
Our reporter, Nicole McBride, attended the inquest of a dad from Crowthorne who died after signs of deadly sepsis were missed at Royal Berkshire Hospital.
During the inquest, multiple medical professionals gave statements which found that just one senior doctor was on duty at Royal Berkshire Hospital on the night a Crowthorne dad died after signs he contracted deadly sepsis were missed.
Carpet fitter Michael Nye, from Crowthorne, suffered a cardiac arrest on November 15, 2022, just hours after he arrived feeling unwell and presenting with symptoms of the fatal condition.
He died from Strep A and sepsis at the start of a national outbreak that killed at least two children.
At Reading Coroner’s Court, the court was told how there were “significant failings” into the care Mr Nye received after it took more than three hours for his blood test results to be seen by doctors when he had been flagged as the “sickest patient” on the ward.
Read more here
Sellebrity Soccer at Sandhurst FC
Dozens of celebrities and TV personalities flocked to Bracknell for the third annual Sellebrity Soccer match in memory of a local lad, Ethan Treharne.
Sportsmen, soap actors, and social media and reality TV stars took to the field at Sandhurst FC where they went head-to-head.
The charity football match which is set to raise thousands of pounds for Brain Tumour Research, will also be a celebration of Ethan Treharne’s life and will mark his 20th birthday after passing away in November 2021 of a terminal brain tumour.
Both celebs and spectators alike were quick to praise the amazing effort that was put behind the day. Love Island contestant, Jake Cornish said: “We’re looking forward to it. Sun’s out, and there are a lot of people here as usual. This is my third time here in Sandhurst and there are a few familiar faces that I remember, including some new ones on the team. “I’ve got a good feeling about today.”
Read more here
February
Tribute paid to ‘little warrior’ Jasmine Freeman
The family of an eight-year-old Bracknell schoolgirl has paid tribute to their “little warrior” saying that she “made the world a better place”.
In January 2023, Bracknell born Jasmine Freeman was given 12 months to live following a shocking diagnosis of an inoperable midline glioma brain tumour after experiencing double vision and sore eyes.
Over the past year, the support she has received from people across the world has been an inspiration to others battling the horrible disease and to people watching her fight in the face of adversity.
Jasmine passed away on Sunday, January 28 at the Alexander Devine Children’s Hospice in Maidenhead surrounded by her family and loved ones.
The ‘devastated’ family expressed their gratitude to the ‘caring’ nursing staff at the hospice who made sure that they had everything they needed at that heartbreaking time.
Read more here
Off-duty cops ‘appalled’ by lack of response
Staff and customers were left shocked at the lack of response after a shot was fired through the window of Sultan Balti House restaurant in Great Hollands Square.
The suspected shooting shattered the window of an Indian restaurant has left staff and diners in shock as the terrifying incident unfolded in Bracknell.
The incident occurred around 7.20pm on February 13.
Despite calls to 999 and 101, Thames Valley Police decided not to attend. Retired police officer and local councillor Roy Bailey said there were two off-duty Met cops there at the time who were “appalled” by the response and would be making a formal complaint.
Read more here
Barclay’s bank closure
Barclays bank made the decision to close their Bracknell town centre branch in May 2024.
Disgruntled Barclays customers have labelled the decision to close the Bracknell town centre branch “ridiculous and insulting” following the bank’s announcement.
Although a recent survey showed that only 130 people used the branch as their sole form of banking, the bank has received kick-back from the local community.
Some who feel they will be affected by the imminent closure include elderly customers and those living with disabilities.
This was just one of the many physical bank closures that took place over the last few years.
Read more here
Sandhurst fish and chip shop celebrate 38 years of ‘outstanding’ service
The excited owners of a family-owned traditional fish and chip shop in Sandhurst celebrated their latest top hygiene rating after 38 years of ‘outstanding’ service.
Skippers Fish and Chips, located on Yorktown Road in College Town, Sandhurst, was opened on March 3, 1986, by Alan and Wendy Hill.
Over the last three decades, the traditional eatery has maintained a top food hygiene rating and customer satisfaction.
Alan expressed his joy at their latest top-tier rating after their inspection on February 13, 2024.
Read more here
March
A special investigation was undertaken by the local democracy reporter at The Bracknell News.
The report, ‘What’s happening behind the scenes at Bracknell’s strictest school’ was published after multiple stories from students and parents at Brackenhale School.
Few issues have attracted such controversy, strong feelings and sharply divided opinions in Bracknell News as the behaviour policy at Brakenhale School.
Interviews over the years told us of children go hungry during short lunch breaks, students coming home in tears, and being left in fear of detention for not having a pen.
But the stories also drew a response from parents who said they found the regime at Brakenhale was encouraging their children to become more responsible and confident.
Radical plans for Bracknell Town Centre
Radical plans to replace Bracknell bus station and remove the High Street car park were revealed in March.
The local democracy service reported a masterplan has given a first glimpse of what Bracknell town centre could look like in the years and decades to come with big changes proposed.
The next phase of the town’s regeneration could transform some areas entirely, describing a town centre that is ‘vibrant and welcoming’.
The Lexicon will still be at the centre of the town centre but development along the outskirts will help create a more ‘outward looking and welcoming approach’.
Perhaps the biggest change is the proposed replacement of Bracknell bus station with a new ‘market square’.
Read more here
Schoolboy appears at Crufts
A nine-year-old Crowthorne school boy, who raised £11,500 for Stand Up to Cancer, made a special appearance during Channel 4’s ‘Crufts’ last weekend.
The UK’s most famous dog show aired from Thursday, March 7 to Sunday, March 10 and showcased the best and most talented dogs across the UK. Charlie Woodhouse raised the money during the ‘Walkies Challenge’ despite not having a dog himself.
To help his dad’s best friend who had been diagnosed with a brain tumour, he started walking friends and families’ dogs and seen the donations flood in.
Walking two miles every day, Charlie was determined to complete the 60 miles in a month to help fund research into cutting-edge cancer treatments.
Read more here
Council hears update on plans to relocate Frimley Park Hospital
Frimley Park Hospital bosses have admitted plans to move to a new site could mean some patients from Berkshire may have to go elsewhere. Plans are in the works to move Frimley Park Hospital to a new, much bigger site as the current main hospital building was built using concrete that now risks becoming unsafe.
Bosses say the new hospital will be much bigger and better - but acknowledged the move will affect patients and staff from Berkshire, as they gave an update to Bracknell Forest Council.
Councillor Georgia Pickering said she wanted to make sure that Bracknell residents wouldn’t lose access to the ‘excellent’maternitycare at Frimley Park. She said: “Residents across Bracknell including myself have been lucky enough to choose Frimley Park to have our babies in, and maternity care.
“I would like to make sure that the change of venue doesn’t mean that people in this borough no longer have the excellent maternity care that Frimley Park has offered.”
Read more here
April
Police arrest 21 migrants found in back of lorry
Police descended on the A322 as motorists saw officers stop and search a lorry heading toward Bracknell. Now it has been confirmed that 21 people were arrested at the scene for immigration offences on Thursday, April 4.
Thames Valley Police worked with Surrey Police and Home Office Immigration on the incident. Reports from the scene told of around a dozen police cars and officers present as people were pulled from the lorry.
Thames Valley Police closed the carriageways of the A322 towards Bracknell on Bagshot Road where it is the Bracknell Road. Diversions were in place, but the incident had a significant impact on travel for over three hours. The road reopened shortly after midday.
Read more here
Pride of Bracknell Forest Awards
Hundreds of members of the community turned out in their finery to this year’s Pride of Bracknell Forest Awards. Held at the Royal Sandhurst Military Academy on Friday April 19, the event was created to recognise the best and brightest individuals, teams and businesses across the borough.
Nominees were put forward by their community for their dedication to their chosen category. Sean Taylor, the chair of the Pride of Bracknell Awards Committee, welcomed award nominees, winners and guests to the sparkling evening following a cocktail reception at the royal venue.
Read more here
May
Twin who fought crocodile attacking her sister is on King’s gallantry list
A TWIN who saved her sister from a crocodile attack will receive a bravery honour after being included on the King’s first Civilian Gallantry List.
Georgia Laurie, 31, from Sandhurst, punched the reptile in the face when it attacked her twin Melissa while they were in Mexico in June 2021.
Both women were seriously hurt but survived after treatment, and now Georgia will receive the King’s Gallantry Medal, which acknowledges exemplary acts of bravery.
The twins were swimming in a lagoon near Puerto Escondido when Melissa was dragged under the water. Melissa survived with an open fracture to her wrist, severe puncture wounds to the abdomen and many injuries to her leg and foot, while Georgia was bitten on her hand.
Read more here
Novello Theatre
The Save the Novello Theatre campaign has been a huge story that has developed over 2024.
As a council-owned building, the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead were accused of ‘scandalous’ neglect for allowing it to fall into a state of disrepair by turning a blind eye.
Councillors reacted in fury after learning that Novello Theatre in Sunninghill ended up in a dilapidated state while in the care of its former owner Redroof Theatre School as the local authority allegedly did not enforce its policies.
The lease agreement between the theatre school and the Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead Council meant the tenant was required to repair and update any damage or wear and tear that occurred during its 15 years of ownership.
The Deck
Hopes that The Deck could be opened up for temporary food stalls or entertainment have been crushed after its private landowners said they can’t afford it.
Bracknell Forest Council hoped that the empty patch of land on High Street in Bracknell’s town centre could be opened up for temporary uses, after plans to redevelop it fell through last year.
But its private landowner - the Bracknell Regeneration Partnership (BRP) - has said the cost of making the land safe for temporary uses would be too high.
Read more here
Fire at Broadmoor
Emergency services rushed to the former site of Broadmoor psychiatric hospital when a fire broke out in the premises.
The fire started around 9.30am and at its height had around 40 firefighters in attendance to get the blaze under control.
Crews from Crowthorne, Bracknell, Ascot, Wokingham, Wokingham Road, Whitley Wood, Caversham Road and Slough were scrambled to the scene.
Paul Bremble from RBFRS said: “This was a significant fire at a derelict building on the old Broadmoor Hospital site which required a large response from our service and our partners.” He said the firehad caused ‘significant damage inside the building
Read more here
June
Sudden death at Jameston
Residents were shocked when a large police presence and cordon were spotted in Jameston in Bracknell Forest.
Police reported that a 26-year-old woman died suddenly on a residential street.
Thames Valley Police and the South Central Ambulance Service were called to the scene around 7.41am on Tuesday, June 4.
A 27-year-old man from Wokingham was arrested for the suspected murder of the woman from Bagshot, Surrey.
Photographs which were taken at the scene showed a blue tent erected and zones near garages closed off.
Read more here
Closure of Coffee Barker in The Lexicon
Shoppers were shocked when it was announced that a popular coffee shop was forced to close with only a few days notice.
The closure was due to soaring costs and rent and rates increases in the Bracknell shopping complex.
On Wednesday, June 12, the manager of Coffee Barker Manj Kaur received a shocking phone call with the news that her 10 hardworking employees would be made jobless.
The Coffee Barker manager expressed her sadness and disappointment after five and a half years with the business.
According to Coffee Barker Co, business rates in the Lexicon have gone as high as £100,000 a year, making it near impossible for small/independent shops to survive in The Lexicon.
Read more here
Royal Ascot
Royal Ascot was opened by the King and Queen on Tuesday, June as the world-famous racing event took place between 17th - Saturday 21st June.
Thousands of race-goers turned out in their masses dressed in the finest millinery and stylish dresses.
A host of celebrities attended the Royal Enclosure including many members of the Royal Family.
Read more here
Bracknell dad takes on 12,000ft skydive to raise money for school’s sensory room
A determined Bracknell dad has raised over £1,000 for his daughter’s school after completing a ‘terrifying’ sky-dive last month.
Darren Teverson, whose daughter attends Harmans Water Primary School, decided to take on the challenge to raise funds for a new sensory room at Harmans Water Primary School.
Both Darren, 50, and his 70-year-old mother-in-law headed to Headcorn on May 25, where they completed the 12,000 ft fall.
Darren, whose daughter is autistic, said that this room will help pupils like his daughter who are sensitive to loud noises, lights, and busy environments.
